title: Tutorial: Blockchain Explorer with Raspberry Pi
summary: This tutorial provides a step-by-step guide on how to set up the Chain-Grabber module from the Ergo Blockchain Explorer on a Raspberry Pi device. It covers the prerequisites, preparing the Raspberry Pi, installing Java, sbt, and PostgreSQL, and setting up the database schema. The goal is to enable developers and data scientists to store the Ergo blockchain data in a standardized database format using a Raspberry Pi.

qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the Chain-Grabber module in the Ergo Blockchain Explorer?
qa_pairs.answer: The Chain-Grabber module is used to store the Ergo blockchain to a standardized database format on a Raspberry Pi device.

qa_pairs.question: What are the minimum requirements for setting up the Chain-Grabber module on a Raspberry Pi?
qa_pairs.answer: The minimum requirements are: Raspberry Pi with official OS installed, minimum 60GB of disk space available, and SSH enabled with stable internet connection.

qa_pairs.question: What are the first steps in preparing the Raspberry Pi for the Chain-Grabber module?
qa_pairs.answer: The first steps are to run the commands 'sudo apt update' and 'sudo apt full-upgrade' to update the system.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Ergo Blockchain Explorer (backend) and where can it be found?
qa_pairs.answer: The Ergo Blockchain Explorer (backend) is the source of the Chain-Grabber module, and it can be found at the GitHub repository https://github.com/ergoplatform/explorer-backend.

qa_pairs.question: Who is the target audience for this tutorial?
qa_pairs.answer: The target audience for this tutorial is developers and data scientists interested in storing the Ergo blockchain to a standardized database format using a Raspberry Pi.

sections.heading: Tutorial: Blockchain Explorer with Raspberry Pi
How to setup the Chain-Grabber module on a Raspberry Pi device
sections.content:
This is a guide for developers and data scientists interested in storing the Ergo blockchain to a standardized database format using a Raspberry Pi.

We will focus specifically on the Chain Grabber module from the [Ergo Blockchain Explorer (backend)](https://github.com/ergoplatform/explorer-backend).

sections.heading: Prerequisites
sections.content: * Raspberry Pi with official OS installed * Minimum 60GB of disk space available * SSH enabled with stable internet connection

sections.heading: Preparing the RPi
sections.content:
```bash
sudo apt update
sudo apt full-upgrade
```

sections.heading: Download sbt
sections.content:
```bash
echo "deb https://repo.scala-sbt.org/scalasbt/debian /" | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/sbt.list
curl -sL "https://keyserver.ubuntu.com/pks/lookup?op=get&search=0x2EE0EA64E40A89B84B2DF73499E82A75642AC823" | sudo apt-key add
sudo apt update
sudo apt install sbt
```

sections.heading: Download and unzip precompiled JAR
sections.content:
If you are reading this in the future, please visit the [code release repo](https://github.com/ergoplatform/explorer-backend/releases) and replace it with the appropriate version.

```bash
wget https://github.com/ergoplatform/explorer-backend/archive/refs/tags/<version>.zip

unzip explorer-backend-<version>
```

sections.heading: Install PostgreSQL
sections.content:
In the code snippet below, we created "ergo" as the username.

```bash
sudo apt install postgresql
sudo su postgres
createuser ergo -P --interactive
```

sections.heading: Setup and load database schema
sections.content:
```bash
psql
create database explorer;
\c explorer;
\i /explorer-backend-9.4.3/modules/explorer-core/src/main/resources/db/V9__Schema.sql
```
The final line of code above executes a SQL script that creates a bunch of tables and indices to be populated later by the Chain Grabber.

sections.heading: Update app config
sections.content:
This is where you need to edit the database username and password you set up earlier. 

```bash
sudo nano explorer-backend-9.4.3/modules/chain-grabber/src/main/resources/application.conf
```

sections.heading: Launch chain-grabber
sections.content:
Run the following command from within the `explorer-backend` directory. 
```bash
sbt chain-grabber/run
```

sections.heading: Validate
sections.content:
If all goes well, the code below returns the latest block height that was stored in the database.

```bash
select max(height) from node_headers;
```
